awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Access Network: Supporting Retention and Representation in Physics Through an Alliance of Campus-Based Diversity Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports an effort to expand and enrich the COMPASS program at UC Berkeley, which is aimed at improving the education and retention of under-represented students (primarily in Physics). There are five universities with similar programs based on the COMPASS model: University of Colorado Boulder, University of Maryland College Park, Rochester Institute of Technology, Chicago State University, and Arizona State University.  This project joins these institutions and UC Berkeley to form the Access Network, designed to develop best practices through shared expertise.  The Access network will support the development of programs intended to improve diversity and access in physics by innovating strategies to build Compass-like programs in new contexts. The network will enhance the efforts of each individual site, build knowledge of best practices for launching new programs, and share this knowledge with the physics community. A robust evaluation of the project will identify the impact of the network on supporting diversity programs and how it contributes to the dissemination of successful strategies and program elements.

The Access network will: (a) empower students and faculty - especially those from marginalized and/or underrepresented groups - as agents in the design, implementation, and iterative improvement of retention efforts, (b) facilitate communication and community among those involved in such efforts, and (c) create and maintain a repository of materials and strategies, all in order to (d) support local communities in adapting these materials and program elements to their unique contexts and populations. To achieve these goals, the project will engage in the following activities: (1) an annual assembly of the member programs, (2) inter-program communication through regular conference calls and inter-institutional travel, (3) documentation of local and inter-institutional innovations, and (4) synthesis and dissemination of member programs' educational materials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In this project, STEM (science, technology, engineering and math) student support organizations from colleges and universities across the country are networked together, forming the Access Network.  Student support organizations are programs which foster student success, retention, and professional development in STEM through mentoring, community buildign, research exposure, and other strategies.  The primary intellectual merit outcome of this project is centered around the formation of new knowledge about strategies for STEM student success and retention, a greater understanding of how to foster equity and inclusion within physical science and STEM communities, and the benefits of engaging student leadership in such programs.  This knowledge was disseminated at annual meetings of the network, documents, and conferences. The broader impacts of this project include: engaging student leaders from each of the nine participating sites as co-organizers of Access Network activities, which provides professional development opportuntities to these student leaders;  benefiting the nine participating sites through the sharing of resources; modeling an inclusive culture; and, combating isolation through networking.In addition to benefitting the participating Access Network sites, the knowledge generated and the leadership training impacts the formation of additional student support programs. As an example of the impact of leadership training, alumni from the Access Network have used the knowledge gained through participaitng to start programs at new institutions after graduating from their original Access Network site.   With an estimated 75 participating undergraduates and 15 graduate students per site, roughly 810 students are impacted by Access Network activities annually.  Significantly, each of these sites serves students historically underrepresented in the physical sciences including women, students of color, LGBTQ+ students, students with disabilities, and students at the intersections of these identities. 


 

 


Last Modified: 09/21/2021
Modified by: Anna Zaniewski
